Bandwidth Allocation for Multiple Federated Learning Services in Wireless Edge Networks

Jie¬†Xu, Heqiang¬†Wang, Lixing¬†Chen J. Xu, H. Wang and L. Chen are with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, USA.
Abstract

This paper studies a federated learning (FL) system, where multiple FL services co-exist in a wireless network and share common wireless resources. It fills the void of wireless resource allocation for multiple simultaneous FL services in the existing literature. Our method designs a two-level resource allocation framework comprising intra-service resource allocation and inter-service resource allocation. The intra-service resource allocation problem aims to minimize the length of FL rounds by optimizing the bandwidth allocation among the clients of each FL service. Based on this, an inter-service resource allocation problem is further considered, which distributes bandwidth resources among multiple simultaneous FL services. We consider both cooperative and selfish providers of the FL services. For cooperative FL service providers, we design a distributed bandwidth allocation algorithm to optimize the overall performance of multiple FL services, meanwhile cater to the fairness among FL services and the privacy of clients. For selfish FL service providers, a new auction scheme is designed with the FL service owners as the bidders and the network provider as the auctioneer. The designed auction scheme strikes a balance between the overall FL performance and fairness. Our simulation results show that the proposed algorithms outperform other benchmarks under various network conditions.

I Introduction

Today‚Äôs mobile devices are generating an unprecedented amount of data every day. Leveraging the recent success of machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI), this rich data has the potential to power a wide range of new functionalities and services, such as learning the activities of smart phone users, predicting health events from wearable devices or adapting to pedestrian behavior in autonomous vehicles. With the help of multi-access edge computing (MEC) servers, ML models can be quickly trained/updated using this data to adapt to the changing environment without moving the data to the remote cloud data center, which is envisioned in intelligent next-generation communication systems [1]. Furthermore, due to the growing storage and computational power of mobile devices as well as privacy concerns associated with uploading personal data, it is increasingly attractive to store and process data directly on mobile devices. Federate learning (FL) [2] is thus proposed as a new distributed ML framework, where mobile devices collaboratively train a shared ML model with the coordination of an edge server while keeping all the training data on device, thereby decoupling the ability to do ML from the need to upload/store the data to/in a public entity.

A typical FL service involves a number of mobile devices (a.k.a., participating clients) and an edge server (a.k.a., a parameter server) to train a ML model, which lasts for a number of learning rounds. In each round, the clients download the current ML model from the server, improve it by learning from their local data, and then upload the individual model updates to the server; the server then aggregates the local updates to improve the shared model. For example, the seminal work [3] proposed the FedAvg algorithm in which the global model is obtained by averaging the parameters of local models. Although other FL algorithms differ in the specifics, the majority of them follow the same procedure. Because the clients work in the same wireless network to download and upload models, how to allocate the limited wireless bandwidth among the participating clients has a crucial impact on the resulting FL speed and efficiency. Therefore, resource allocation for wireless FL systems is attracting much attention recently in the wireless communications community [4, 5]. Compared to resource allocation in traditional throughput-maximizing wireless networks, the resource allocation objective and outcome become considerably different for wireless FL due to its unique requirements and characteristics.

Although existing works have made meaningful progress towards efficient resource allocation for wireless FL, they share the common limitation that only a single FL service was considered. As ML-powered applications grow and become more diverse, it is anticipated that the wireless network will host multiple co-existing FL services, the set of which may also dynamically change over time. See Figure 1 for an illustration of the multi-FL service scenario. The presence of multiple FL services makes resource allocation for wireless FL much more challenging. First, the achievable FL performance depends on not only intra-service resource allocation among the participating clients within each FL service but also inter-service resource allocation among different FL services, and these two levels of allocation decisions are also strongly coupled. Second, the FL service providers may adopt different FL algorithms and choose different configurations (e.g., number of participating clients, number of epochs of local training, etc.), yet this information is not always available to the wireless network operator due to privacy concerns when making resource allocation decisions. Third, because FL service providers have their individual goals, they may have incentives to untruthfully reveal their valuation of the wireless bandwidth if by doing so they gain advantages in the inter-service bandwidth allocation. Without the correct information, there is no guarantee on the overall system performance. Finally, as in any multi-user system, resource allocation should strike a good balance between efficiency and fairness ‚Äì every FL service provider should obtain a reasonable share of the wireless resource to train their ML models using FL.

In this paper, we make an initial effort to study wireless FL with multiple co-existing FL services, which share the same bandwidth to train their respective ML models. Our focus is on the efficient bandwidth allocation among different FL services as well as among the participating clients within each FL service, thereby understanding the interplay between these two levels of allocation decisions. Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    We formalize a two-level bandwidth allocation problem for multiple FL services co-existing in the wireless network, which may start and complete at different time depending on their own demand and FL requirements. The model is general enough for any FL algorithm that involves downloading, local learning, uploading and global aggregation in each learning round, and hence has wide applicability in real-world systems. In addition, we explicitly take fairness into consideration when optimizing bandwidth allocation to ensure that no FL service is starved of bandwidth.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We consider two use cases depending on the nature/goals of the FL service providers. In the first case, FL service providers are fully cooperative to maximize the overall system performance. For this, we design a distributed optimization algorithm based on dual decomposition to solve the two-level bandwidth allocation problem. The algorithm keeps all FL-related information at the individual FL service provider side without sharing it with the network operator, thereby reducing the communication overhead and enhancing privacy protection.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We further consider a second case where FL service providers are selfishly maximizing their own performance. To address the selfishness issue, we design a multi-bid auction mechanism, which is able to elicit the FL service providers‚Äô truthful valuation of bandwidth based on their submitted bids. With a fairness-adjusted ex post charge, the proposed auction mechanism is able to make a tunable trade-off between efficiency and fairness.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II discusses related works. Section III builds the system model. Section IV formulates the problem for the cooperative case and develops a distributed bandwidth allocation algorithm. Section V studies the selfish service providers case and develops a multi-auction mechanism. Section VI performs simulations. Concluding remarks are made in Section VII.

II Related Work

A lot of research has been devoted to tackling various challenges of FL, including but not limited to developing new optimization and model aggregation methods [6, 7, 8], handling non-i.i.d. and unbalanced datasets [9, 10, 11], dealing with the straggler problem [12], preserving model and data privacy [13, 14], and ensuring fairness [15, 16]. A comprehensive review of these challenges can be found in [17, 18, 19]. In particular, the communication aspect of FL has been recognized as a primary bottleneck due to the tension between uploading a large amount of model data for aggregation and the limited network resource to support this transmission, especially in a wireless environment. In this regard, early research on communication-efficient FL largely focuses on reducing the amount of transmitted data while assuming that the underlying communication channel has been established, e.g., updating clients with significant training improvement [20], compressing the gradient vectors via quantization [21], or accelerating training using sparse or structured updates [22]. More recent research starts to address this problem from a more communication system perspective, e.g., using a hierarchical FL network architecture [23] that allows partial model aggregation, and leveraging the wireless transmission property to perform analog model aggregation over the air [24].

As wireless networks are envisioned as a main deployment scenario of FL, wireless resource allocation for FL is another active research topic. Many existing works [25, 26, 5] study the trade-off between local model update and global model aggregation. Client selection is essential to enable FL at scale and address the straggler problem. Different types of joint bandwidth allocation and client scheduling policies [27, 28, 29, 30, 31] have been proposed to either minimize the training loss or the training time. In all these works, resource allocation is carried out among clients of a single FL service, while assuming that the FL service itself has already received dedicated resource. In stark contrast, our paper studies a network consisting of multiple co-existing FL services and performs resource allocation at both the FL service level and the client level. We notice that a related problem where multiple FL services are being trained at the same time is also considered in a recent work [32]. In that paper, different FL services run on the same set of clients and a joint computation and communication resource scheduling problem is studied. In our paper, different FL services have their separate client sets which may experience very different channel qualities and hence we focus only on the bandwidth allocation problem. Moreover, while [32] assumed that all clients are obedient, we study the possible selfish nature of FL service providers and highlight bandwidth allocation fairness.

Considering each FL service as a ‚Äúuser‚Äù, our problem is a special type of resource allocation problems for multi-user wireless networks. While many concepts and techniques adopted in this paper, including proportional fairness [33], dual decomposition [34] and multi-bid auction [35], have seen applications in other multi-user wireless resource allocation domains, applying them in multi-service FL requires special treatment as two levels of resource allocation are involved in our problem. In particular, there is no closed-form expression of how the performance (i.e., learning speed) of a FL service depends on the resource allocation among its clients. Therefore, understanding the inter-dependency of intra-service and inter-service bandwidth allocation is essential. Furthermore, we put an emphasis on the resource fairness among different FL services by designing a new fairness-adjusted multi-bid auction mechanism in the selfish FL service provider case, thereby achieving a tunable tradeoff between efficiency and fairness. We point out that there are some existing works [36, 37, 38, 39] on designing incentive mechanisms for client participation of a single FL service. These works are very different from our paper in terms of both the problem and the approaches, and do not consider fairness when designing the mechanism.

III System Model

We consider a wireless network where machine learning models are trained using Federated Learning (FL). The wireless network has a total bandwidth BùêµB, and the network operator has to allocate this bandwidth among concurrent FL services when needed to enable their individual training. Because new FL services may start and old FL services may finish over time, bandwidth allocation has to be periodically performed to adapt to the current active FL services. Therefore, we divide time into periods and let the length of a period be TùëáT. At the beginning of each period iùëñi, a set ùí©isubscriptùí©ùëñ\mathcal{N}_{i} of FL services are active and require wireless bandwidth to carry out their training. These services are either newly initiated services in period iùëñi or continuing services from the previous period. A FL service finishes and hence exits the wireless network when a certain termination criteria is satisfied (e.g., the training loss is below a threshold, the testing accuracy is above a threshold, or other convergence criterion), which usually varies across FL services and are pre-specified by the corresponding service provider. Therefore, a FL service may span multiple periods. The wall clock time (i.e. the number of periods) that a FL service takes to finish depends on the difficulty and other inherent characteristics of the service itself as well as how much wireless resource is allocated to this service in each period for which it stays and how this bandwidth is further allocated among its participating clients. In what follows, we first formulate the client-level (i.e., intra-service) bandwidth allocation problem and then describe the service-level (i.e., inter-service) bandwidth allocation problem.

III-A Intra-Service Bandwidth Allocation

To understand how bandwidth allocation affects FL performance, let us consider a single representative FL service nùëõn in one period (period index iùëñi is dropped for conciseness). Suppose that this service is allocated with a bandwidth bnsubscriptùëèùëõb_{n} in this period, which is further allocated among its participating clients, the set of which is denoted by ùí¶nsubscriptùí¶ùëõ\mathcal{K}_{n}. We consider a synchronized FL model for each FL service, where a number of FL rounds take place in a period. Nonetheless, different FL services do not have to be synchronized ‚Äì they learn at their own pace. See Figure 2 for an illustration.

III-B Inter-Service Bandwidth Allocation

In a period, multiple active FL services may be active and require wireless bandwidth to carry out learning. Since they share a total bandwidth BùêµB, how this bandwidth is allocated among different services will determine their achievable learning frequencies fn‚àó‚Äã(bn)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõf^{*}_{n}(b_{n}), thus the convergence speed in terms of the wall clock time. In this paper, we consider two scenarios depending on the goals of the FL service providers and how inter-service bandwidth allocation is implemented. In the first scenario, all FL service providers are cooperative, and their goal is to maximize the FL performance of the overall system. Therefore, it is equivalent to the network operator solving a system-wide optimization problem. In the second scenario, the FL service providers are selfish who care about only their own FL performance. As these service providers are competing for the limited bandwidth resource, addressing their incentive issues is crucial. In this paper, we design a fairness-adjusted multi-bid auction mechanism for the inter-service bandwidth allocation in this case. In the following two sections, we discuss these two scenarios separately.

IV Cooperative service providers

In the cooperative service providers scenario, the network operator directly decides the bandwidth allocation to maximize the overall system performance. As in any multi-user network, bandwidth allocation for multi-service FL has to address both efficiency and fairness ‚Äì every active FL service should get a reasonable share of the bandwidth. Thus, we adopt the notion of proportional fairness [33], a metric widely used in multi-user resource allocation, and aim to solve the following optimization problem:

maxb1,‚Ä¶,bN‚Äã‚àën=1Nlog‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(bn))subscriptsubscriptùëè1‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅ1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõ\displaystyle\max_{b_{1},...,b_{N}}~{}~{}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))
subject to ‚àën=1Nbn=B‚Äãand‚Äãfn‚àó‚Äã(bn)‚Äãsolves‚Äã(‚Äã1‚Äã),‚àÄnsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëèùëõùêµandsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõsolvesitalic-(1italic-)for-allùëõ\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}=B~{}~{}\text{and}~{}~{}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})~{}\text{solves}~{}\eqref{clientBA},\forall n (2)

where we drop the period index iùëñi and let NùëÅN be the number of active FL services in the period for conciseness. The objective function adds a ‚Äú1‚Äù inside the logarithmic to ensure that the function value is always non-negative. This change has very little impact on the final allocation since the frequency is often much larger than 1 in a period. Note also that the above inter-service bandwidth allocation problem Eqn.¬†(2) implicitly incorporates the intra-service problem as fn‚àó‚Äã(bn)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõf^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) is the solution to Eqn.¬†(1).

tn,kC+Œ±n,k/bn,k=tn‚àó,‚àÄksubscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòsubscriptùõºùëõùëòsubscriptùëèùëõùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë°ùëõfor-allùëò\displaystyle t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}+\alpha_{n,k}/b_{n,k}=t^{*}_{n},\forall k (6)

Therefore, the optimal tn‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùë°ùëõt^{*}_{n} solves the following equality,

‚àëkŒ±n,ktn‚àó‚àítn,kC=bnsubscriptùëòsubscriptùõºùëõùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòsubscriptùëèùëõ\displaystyle\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{t^{*}_{n}-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}}=b_{n} (7)

Although we do not have a closed-form solution of tn‚àó‚Äã(bn)subscriptsuperscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëèùëõt^{*}_{n}(b_{n}), a bi-section algorithm can be constructed to easily solve the above problem to obtain the optimal tn‚àó‚Äã(bn)subscriptsuperscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëèùëõt^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) and consequently the optimal frequency fn‚àó‚Äã(bn)=1/tn‚àó‚Äã(bn)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõ1subscriptsuperscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëèùëõf^{*}_{n}(b_{n})=1/t^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) as a function of bnsubscriptùëèùëõb_{n}. Furthermore, the property of fn‚àó‚Äã(bn)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõf^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) can be characterized in the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

fn‚àó‚Äã(bn)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõf^{*}_{n}(b_{n}) is a differentiable, increasing and concave function for bn>0subscriptùëèùëõ0b_{n}>0.

Proof.

Let us consider the inverse function bn‚Äã(fn)subscriptùëèùëõsubscriptùëìùëõb_{n}(f_{n}) defined by Eqn. (7). It is easy to see that for fn‚àà[0,1/maxk‚Å°tn,kC)subscriptùëìùëõ01subscriptùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòf_{n}\in[0,1/\max_{k}t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}), bn‚Äã(Fn)subscriptùëèùëõsubscriptùêπùëõb_{n}(F_{n}) is a monotonically increasing function in fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} with bn‚Äã(0)=0subscriptùëèùëõ00b_{n}(0)=0 and bn‚Äã(fn)‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùëèùëõsubscriptùëìùëõb_{n}(f_{n})\to\infty as fn‚Üí1/maxk‚Å°tn,kc‚Äãp‚Üísubscriptùëìùëõ1subscriptùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë°ùëêùëùùëõùëòf_{n}\to 1/\max_{k}t^{cp}_{n,k}. Therefore, for bn‚â•0subscriptùëèùëõ0b_{n}\geq 0, fn‚Äã(bn)subscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõf_{n}(b_{n}) is also monotonically increasing. The first-order derivative of bn‚Äã(fn)subscriptùëèùëõsubscriptùëìùëõb_{n}(f_{n}) is

bn‚Ä≤=d‚Äãbnd‚Äãfn=d‚Äãbnd‚Äãtn‚Äãd‚Äãtnd‚Äãfn=‚àëkŒ±n,k(1‚àítn,kC‚Äãfn)2>0,‚àÄfn‚àà[0,1/maxk‚Å°tn,kC)formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëè‚Ä≤ùëõùëësubscriptùëèùëõùëësubscriptùëìùëõùëësubscriptùëèùëõùëësubscriptùë°ùëõùëësubscriptùë°ùëõùëësubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëòsubscriptùõºùëõùëòsuperscript1subscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòsubscriptùëìùëõ20for-allsubscriptùëìùëõ01subscriptùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëò\displaystyle b^{\prime}_{n}=\frac{db_{n}}{df_{n}}=\frac{db_{n}}{dt_{n}}\frac{dt_{n}}{df_{n}}=\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{(1-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}f_{n})^{2}}>0,\forall f_{n}\in[0,1/\max_{k}t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}) (8)

Therefore, fn‚Äã(bn)subscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõf_{n}(b_{n}) is differentiable for bn‚â•0subscriptùëèùëõ0b_{n}\geq 0 and

fn‚Ä≤=d‚Äãfnd‚Äãbn=(‚àëkŒ±n,k(1‚àítn,kC‚Äãfn)2)‚àí1>0,‚àÄbn‚â•0formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëì‚Ä≤ùëõùëësubscriptùëìùëõùëësubscriptùëèùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëòsubscriptùõºùëõùëòsuperscript1subscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòsubscriptùëìùëõ210for-allsubscriptùëèùëõ0\displaystyle f^{\prime}_{n}=\frac{df_{n}}{db_{n}}=\left(\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{(1-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}f_{n})^{2}}\right)^{-1}>0,\forall b_{n}\geq 0 (9)

The second-order derivative fn‚Ä≤‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùëõf^{\prime\prime}_{n} can also be computed as follows:

fn‚Ä≤‚Ä≤=‚àí(‚àëkŒ±n,k(1‚àítn,kC‚Äãfn)2)‚àí2‚Äã(‚àëkŒ±n,k‚Äãtn,kC(1‚àítn,kC‚Äãfn)3)<0,‚àÄB‚â•0formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëòsubscriptùõºùëõùëòsuperscript1subscriptsuperscriptùë°ùê∂ùëõùëòsubscriptùëìùëõ22subscriptùëòsubscriptùõºùëõùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòsuperscript1subscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòsubscriptùëìùëõ30for-allùêµ0\displaystyle f^{\prime\prime}_{n}=-\left(\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{(1-t^{C}_{n,k}f_{n})^{2}}\right)^{-2}\left(\sum_{k}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}}{(1-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}f_{n})^{3}}\right)<0,\forall B\geq 0 (10)

This proves that fn‚Äã(bn)subscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõf_{n}(b_{n}) is a concave function for bn‚â•0subscriptùëèùëõ0b_{n}\geq 0. ‚àé

With Lemma 1, it is straightforward to see that the inter-service bandwidth allocation problem (2) is a convex optimization problem.

Proposition 1.

The inter-service bandwidth allocation problem (2) is an equality-constrained convex optimization problem.

Proof.

Because f‚àósuperscriptùëìf^{*} is concave, log\log is concave and increasing, the composition log‚Å°(1+f‚àó)1superscriptùëì\log(1+f^{*}) is also a concave function. Then it is straightforward to see that the problem is a concave maximization problem with an equality constraint. ‚àé

IV-B Distributed Algorithm for Inter-Service Bandwidth Allocation

We now proceed with solving the inter-service bandwidth allocation problem. While various centralized algorithms, such the Newton‚Äôs method, can efficiently solve the inter-service problem Eqn. (2) given the fact that it is a convex optimization problem, we prefer a distributed algorithm where individual FL service providers do not share their FL algorithm details and client-level information with each other or the network operator. This way reduces the communication overhead and preserves privacy of the client devices of individual FL service providers. Our algorithm is developed based on dual decomposition [34] as follows.

We first relax the total bandwidth constraint ‚àënbn=Bsubscriptùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùêµ\sum_{n}b_{n}=B to be ‚àënbn‚â§Bsubscriptùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùêµ\sum_{n}b_{n}\leq B, and then form the Lagrangian by relaxing the coupling constraint:

L‚Äã(b1,‚Ä¶,bN,Œª)=‚àënlog‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(bn))‚àíŒª‚Äã(‚àënbn‚àíB)=‚àënLn‚Äã(bn,Œª)+Œª‚ÄãBùêøsubscriptùëè1‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùëÅùúÜsubscriptùëõ1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜsubscriptùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùêµsubscriptùëõsubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜùúÜùêµ\displaystyle L(b_{1},...,b_{N},\lambda)=\sum_{n}\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))-\lambda\left(\sum_{n}b_{n}-B\right)=\sum_{n}L_{n}(b_{n},\lambda)+\lambda B (11)

where ŒªùúÜ\lambda is the Lagrange multipier associated with the total bandwidth constraint, and Ln‚Äã(bn,Œª)=log‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(bn))‚àíŒª‚ÄãbnsubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜ1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜsubscriptùëèùëõL_{n}(b_{n},\lambda)=\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))-\lambda b_{n} is the Lagrangian to be maximized by service provider nùëõn. Such dual decomposition results in each service provider nùëõn solving, for a given ŒªùúÜ\lambda, the following problem

bn‚àó‚Äã(Œª)=arg‚Å°maxbn‚â•0‚Å°Ln‚Äã(bn,Œª)=arg‚Å°maxbn‚â•0‚Å°(log‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(bn))‚àíŒª‚Äãbn)subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõùúÜsubscriptsubscriptùëèùëõ0subscriptùêøùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜsubscriptsubscriptùëèùëõ01subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜsubscriptùëèùëõ\displaystyle b^{*}_{n}(\lambda)=\arg\max_{b_{n}\geq 0}L_{n}(b_{n},\lambda)=\arg\max_{b_{n}\geq 0}\left(\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))-\lambda b_{n}\right) (12)

where the solution is unique due to the strict concavity of fn‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{*}_{n} according to Lemma 1. Specifically, to solve this maximization problem, we only need to solve its first-order condition,

fn‚àó‚Ä≤‚Äã(bn)/(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(bn))=Œªsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõ‚Ä≤subscriptùëèùëõ1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜ\displaystyle{f_{n}^{*}}^{\prime}(b_{n})/(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))=\lambda (13)

which can be converted to solve f‚àósuperscriptùëìf^{*} using

(1+fn‚àó)‚Äã‚àëk‚ààùí¶nŒ±n,k(1‚àítn,kC‚Äãfn‚àó)2=Œª‚àí11subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëòsubscriptùí¶ùëõsubscriptùõºùëõùëòsuperscript1subscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõ2superscriptùúÜ1\displaystyle(1+f^{*}_{n})\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{n}}\frac{\alpha_{n,k}}{(1-t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}f^{*}_{n})^{2}}=\lambda^{-1} (14)

Clearly, the left-hand side is an increasing function of fn‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{*}_{n} for fn‚àó‚àà[0,1/maxk‚Å°tn,kC)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõ01subscriptùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë°Cùëõùëòf^{*}_{n}\in[0,1/\max_{k}t^{\text{C}}_{n,k}) and thus, a simple bi-section algorithm can be devised to solve Eqn. (14) to obtain fn‚àó‚Äã(Œª)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùúÜf^{*}_{n}(\lambda). Then plugging fn‚àó‚Äã(Œª)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùúÜf^{*}_{n}(\lambda) (hence tn‚àó‚Äã(Œª)subscriptsuperscriptùë°ùëõùúÜt^{*}_{n}(\lambda)) into Eqn. (7) yields the optimal bn‚àó‚Äã(Œª)subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõùúÜb^{*}_{n}(\lambda).

Let gn‚Äã(Œª)=maxbn‚â•0‚Å°Ln‚Äã(bn,Œª)=Ln‚Äã(bn‚àó‚Äã(Œª),Œª)subscriptùëîùëõùúÜsubscriptsubscriptùëèùëõ0subscriptùêøùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜsubscriptùêøùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõùúÜùúÜg_{n}(\lambda)=\max_{b_{n}\geq 0}L_{n}(b_{n},\lambda)=L_{n}(b^{*}_{n}(\lambda),\lambda) be the local dual function for service provider nùëõn. Then the master dual problem is

minŒª‚Å°g‚Äã(Œª)=‚àëngn‚Äã(Œª)+Œª‚ÄãBsubject to‚ÄãŒª‚â•0formulae-sequencesubscriptùúÜùëîùúÜsubscriptùëõsubscriptùëîùëõùúÜùúÜùêµsubject toùúÜ0\displaystyle\min_{\lambda}g(\lambda)=\sum_{n}g_{n}(\lambda)+\lambda B~{}~{}~{}~{}\text{subject to}~{}~{}\lambda\geq 0 (15)

Since bn‚àó‚Äã(Œª)subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõùúÜb^{*}_{n}(\lambda) is unique, it follows that the dual function gn‚Äã(Œª)subscriptùëîùëõùúÜg_{n}(\lambda) is differentiable and the following gradient method can be used to iteratively update ŒªùúÜ\lambda:

Œª‚Äã(j+1)=[Œª‚Äã(j)‚àíŒ≥‚Äã(B‚àí‚àënbn‚àó‚Äã(Œª‚Äã(j)))]+ùúÜùëó1superscriptdelimited-[]ùúÜùëóùõæùêµsubscriptùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõùúÜùëó\displaystyle\lambda(j+1)=\left[\lambda(j)-\gamma\left(B-\sum_{n}b^{*}_{n}(\lambda(j))\right)\right]^{+} (16)

where jùëój is the iteration index, Œ≥>0ùõæ0\gamma>0 is a sufficiently small positive step-size, and [‚ãÖ]+superscriptdelimited-[]‚ãÖ[\cdot]^{+} denotes the projection onto the non-negative orthant. The dual variable Œª‚Äã(j)ùúÜùëó\lambda(j) will converge to the dual optimum Œª‚àósuperscriptùúÜ\lambda^{*} as j‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëój\to\infty. Since the duality gap for the inter-service problem Eqn. (2) is zero and the solution to Eqn. (12) is unique, the primal variable bn‚àó‚Äã(Œª‚Äã(j))subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõùúÜùëób^{*}_{n}(\lambda(j)) will also converge to the primal optimal variable bn‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõb^{*}_{n}.

Algorithm 1 summarizes the distributed inter-service bandwidth allocation (DISBA) algorithm. The algorithm works iteratively. In each iteration, the operator sends the current Œª‚Äã(j)ùúÜùëó\lambda(j) to all service providers. Then, each service providers solves for bn‚àó‚Äã(Œª‚Äã(j))subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõùúÜùëób^{*}_{n}(\lambda(j)) using its local information and sends the result to the network operator. The network operator finally updates Œª‚Äã(j+1)ùúÜùëó1\lambda(j+1) for the next iteration‚Äôs computation. The algorithm terminates until ŒªùúÜ\lambda converges.

V Selfish service providers

In the previous section, the distributed inter-service bandwidth allocation works by letting each FL service provider compute the allocated bandwidth bn‚àó‚Äã(Œª‚Äã(j))subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëõùúÜùëób^{*}_{n}(\lambda(j)) given Œª‚Äã(j)ùúÜùëó\lambda(j). This, however, creates an opportunity for a selfish service provider to mis-report its computation result that favors itself but reduces the system performance as a whole. In fact, even if the inter-service bandwidth allocation problem (2) is solved in a centralized way, similar selfish behavior may still undermine the efficient system operation as a selfish service provider may mis-report its FL service and client parameters (e.g., FL workload, client computing power and channel gains etc.), which will alter the frequency function fn‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{*}_{n} used at the operator side. With a wrong frequency function fn‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{*}_{n}, the operator will not be able to determine the true optimal bandwidth allocation.

In this section, we address the selfishness issue in inter-service bandwidth allocation by designing a multi-bid auction mechanism. This auction mechanism will ensure that the FL service providers are using their true FL frequency functions fn‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{*}_{n} when making bandwidth bids.

V-A Multi-bid Auction

First, we describe the general rules of the multi-bid auction mechanism.

V-A1 Bidding

At the beginning of each bandwidth allocation period, each service provider nùëõn submits a set of MùëÄM bids sn={sn1,‚Ä¶,snM}subscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùë†1ùëõ‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëÄùëõs_{n}=\{s^{1}_{n},...,s^{M}_{n}\}. For each m‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,M}ùëö1‚Ä¶ùëÄm\in\{1,...,M\}, snm=(bnm,pnm)subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõs^{m}_{n}=(b^{m}_{n},p^{m}_{n}) is a two-dimensional bid, where bnmsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõb^{m}_{n} is the requested bandwidth and pnmsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõp^{m}_{n} is the unit price that service provider nùëõn is willing to pay to get the requested bandwidth bnmsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõb^{m}_{n}. Without loss of generality, we assume that bids are sorted according to the price such that pn1‚â§pn2‚â§‚Ä¶‚â§pnMsubscriptsuperscriptùëù1ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëù2ùëõ‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëùùëÄùëõp^{1}_{n}\leq p^{2}_{n}\leq...\leq p^{M}_{n}. Let S‚àà‚Ñù+√ó‚Ñù+ùëÜsuperscript‚Ñùsuperscript‚ÑùS\in\mathbb{R}^{+}\times\mathbb{R}^{+} denote the set of multi-bids that a service provider can submit.

V-A2 Bandwidth Allocation and Charges

Once the network operator collects all multi-bids from all service providers, denoted by s={sn}n‚ààùí©ùë†subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëõùëõùí©s=\{s_{n}\}_{n\in\mathcal{N}}, it computes and implements the inter-service bandwidth allocation (b1,‚Ä¶,bN)subscriptùëè1‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùëÅ(b_{1},...,b_{N}). Each service provider nùëõn then further allocates bnsubscriptùëèùëõb_{n} to its clients to perform FL. At the end of the period, the network operator determines the charges (c1,‚Ä¶,cN)subscriptùëê1‚Ä¶subscriptùëêùëÅ(c_{1},...,c_{N}) for all service providers depending on the allocated bandwidth and the realized FL performance.

Now, a couple of issues remain to be addressed. First, how to compute the bandwidth allocation and determine the charges given the service provider-submitted multi-bids? Second, do the service providers have incentives to truthfully report their valuations of the bandwidth? These are the questions to be addressed in the next subsections.

V-B Market Clearing Prices with Full Information

We first consider a simpler case where the service providers truthfully report the complete FL frequency function fn‚àó‚Äã(b),‚àÄnsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèfor-allùëõf^{*}_{n}(b),\forall n to the network operator. This analysis will provide us with insights on how to design bandwidth allocation and charging rules in the more difficult multi-bid auction case.

Recall that fn‚àó‚Äã(b)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèf^{*}_{n}(b) is the optimal FL frequency of service nùëõn if it has bandwidth bùëèb. Taking into account the price paid to obtain this bandwidth, the (net) utility of service provider nùëõn is

un‚Äã(b;p)=fn‚àó‚Äã(b)‚àíp‚ãÖbsubscriptùë¢ùëõùëèùëùsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëè‚ãÖùëùùëè\displaystyle u_{n}(b;p)=f^{*}_{n}(b)-p\cdot b (17)

Now, if the bandwidth were sold at the unit price pùëùp, then service provider nùëõn would buy bn‚Äã(p)=arg‚Å°maxb‚Å°un‚Äã(b;p)subscriptùëèùëõùëùsubscriptùëèsubscriptùë¢ùëõùëèùëùb_{n}(p)=\arg\max_{b}u_{n}(b;p) bandwidth in order to maximize its utility. We call bn‚Äã(p)subscriptùëèùëõùëùb_{n}(p) the bandwidth demand function (BDF), and it is easy to show that bn‚Äã(p)=(fn‚àó‚Ä≤)‚àí1‚Äã(p)subscriptùëèùëõùëùsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõ‚Ä≤1ùëùb_{n}(p)=({f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime})^{-1}(p) by checking the first-order condition of Eqn. (17). On the other hand, if service provider nùëõn requires a bandwidth bùëèb, then the service provider would pay a unit price no more than pn‚Äã(b)=fn‚àó‚Ä≤‚Äã(b)subscriptùëùùëõùëèsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõ‚Ä≤ùëèp_{n}(b)={f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(b). We call pn‚Äã(b)subscriptùëùùëõùëèp_{n}(b) the marginal valuation function (MVF).

V-B1 Market clearing price

With the complete information of fn‚àó‚Äã(b)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèf^{*}_{n}(b) and hence BDF bn‚Äã(p)subscriptùëèùëõùëùb_{n}(p) for all service providers, the network operator can compute the market clearing price (MCP) œÅùúå\rho so that ‚àën=1Nbn‚Äã(œÅ)=Bsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëèùëõùúåùêµ\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}(\rho)=B. One can prove that the MCP is unique and optimal in the sense that it maximizes the total (equivalently, average) FL frequency.

Proposition 2.

The market clearing price œÅùúå\rho is unique and maximizes the total FL frequency ‚àën=1Nfn‚àó‚Äã(bn)superscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõ\sum_{n=1}^{N}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}).

Proof.

According to Lemma 1, fn‚àó‚Ä≤‚Äã(b)superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõ‚Ä≤ùëè{f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(b) is an increasing function. Therefore, the BDF, which is the inverse function of fn‚àó‚Ä≤‚Äã(b)superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõ‚Ä≤ùëè{f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(b) is also increasing. As a result, there exists a unique solution to the increasing function ‚àën=1Nbn‚Äã(pn)=Bsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëèùëõsubscriptùëùùëõùêµ\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}(p_{n})=B.

To show that p¬Ø¬Øùëù\bar{p} maximizes ‚àën=1Nfn‚àó‚Äã(bn)superscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõ\sum_{n=1}^{N}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}), consider the following maximization problem

maxb1,‚Ä¶,bN‚Äã‚àën=1Nfn‚àó‚Äã(bn)‚Äãsubject to‚Äã‚àën=1Nbn=Bsubscriptsubscriptùëè1‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõsubject tosuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëèùëõùêµ\displaystyle\max_{b_{1},...,b_{N}}~{}~{}\sum_{n=1}^{N}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})~{}~{}~{}\text{subject to}~{}~{}\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}=B (18)

This is clearly a convex optimization problem. Consider its Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions. In particular, the stationarity condition is

‚àá‚Äã‚àën=1Nfn‚àó‚Äã(bn)+Œª‚Äã‚àá(‚àën=1Nbn‚àíB)=0‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùúÜ‚àásuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëèùëõùêµ0\displaystyle\nabla\sum_{n=1}^{N}f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})+\lambda\nabla(\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}-B)=0 (19)

where ŒªùúÜ\lambda is the Lagrangian multiplier associated with the constraint. The solution requires

fn‚àó‚Ä≤‚Äã(bn)=Œª,‚àÄnsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõ‚Ä≤subscriptùëèùëõùúÜfor-allùëõ\displaystyle{f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(b_{n})=\lambda,\forall n (20)

Together with the feasibility constraint, this is equivalent to imposing a homogeneous market clearing price. ‚àé

Because bn‚Äã(p)subscriptùëèùëõùëùb_{n}(p) is a monotonically decreasing function in pùëùp, a bi-section algorithm can be easily designed to find the unique market clearing price so that ‚àën=1Nbn‚Äã(œÅ)=Bsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëèùëõùúåùêµ\sum_{n=1}^{N}b_{n}(\rho)=B.

V-B2 Fairness-adjusted costs

One major issue with the above pricing scheme is that it ignores fairness among the service providers: although it maximizes efficiency in terms of the average FL frequency according to Proposition 2, it is possible that the average FL frequency is maximized at an operating point where a few service providers are allocated with most of the bandwidth while some service providers obtain very little bandwidth. In this paper, we design and incorporate a fairness-adjusted charging scheme into the above pricing scheme. The payment of service provider nùëõn now consists of two parts as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    The first part of the payment depends on the amount of bandwidth bnsubscriptùëèùëõb_{n} allocated to the service provider nùëõn, and the unit price pùëùp set by the operator. Specifically, this payment is p‚ãÖbn‚ãÖùëùsubscriptùëèùëõp\cdot b_{n}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The second part of the payment depends on the realized FL frequency fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} of service provider nùëõn. Specifically, service provider nùëõn will be charged a fairness-adjusted cost of Œ±‚ãÖ(fn‚àílog‚Å°(1+fn))‚ãÖùõºsubscriptùëìùëõ1subscriptùëìùëõ\alpha\cdot(f_{n}-\log(1+f_{n})) at the end of the period once fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} has been realized, where Œ±‚àà[0,1]ùõº01\alpha\in[0,1] is a tunable parameter.

With these payments, service provider nùëõn‚Äôs utility becomes

un‚Äã(b;p)=fn‚àó‚Äã(b)‚àíp‚ãÖb‚àíŒ±‚ãÖ(fn‚àó‚Äã(b)‚àílog‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(b)))=gn‚Äã(b)‚àíp‚ãÖbsubscriptùë¢ùëõùëèùëùsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëè‚ãÖùëùùëè‚ãÖùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëè1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèsubscriptùëîùëõùëè‚ãÖùëùùëè\displaystyle u_{n}(b;p)=f^{*}_{n}(b)-p\cdot b-\alpha\cdot(f^{*}_{n}(b)-\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b)))=g_{n}(b)-p\cdot b (21)

where gn‚Äã(b)‚âú(1‚àíŒ±)‚Äãfn‚àó‚Äã(b)+Œ±‚Äãlog‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(b))‚âúsubscriptùëîùëõùëè1ùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèùõº1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèg_{n}(b)\triangleq(1-\alpha)f^{*}_{n}(b)+\alpha\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b)). Comparing this new utility function Eqn. (21) with Eqn. (17), we make the following remarks. First, the fairness-adjusted cost essentially replaces fn‚àó‚Äã(b)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèf^{*}_{n}(b) with gn‚Äã(b)subscriptùëîùëõùëèg_{n}(b). The decision problem remains largely the same except that now we have a different benefit function. Second, in the new utility function Eqn. (17), given any allocated bandwidth bùëèb, it is still in the service provider‚Äôs interest to perform the optimal client-level bandwidth allocation to maximize fn‚Äã(b)subscriptùëìùëõùëèf_{n}(b). This is because gn‚Äã(b)subscriptùëîùëõùëèg_{n}(b) is an increasing function in fn‚Äã(b)subscriptùëìùëõùëèf_{n}(b) for Œ±‚àà[0,1]ùõº01\alpha\in[0,1]. Therefore, we can directly write gn‚Äã(b)subscriptùëîùëõùëèg_{n}(b) as a function of the optimal FL frequency fn‚àó‚Äã(b)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèf^{*}_{n}(b). Third, to charge the fairness-adjusted cost, the network operator does not need to know the exact function fn‚àó‚Äã(b)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèf^{*}_{n}(b). Rather, it only has to know the realized FL frequency fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} at the end of the current period. This is key to achieving fairness in multi-bid auction where FL service providers do not report the complete FL frequency function fn‚àó‚Äã(b)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèf^{*}_{n}(b).

We call dn‚Äã(p)=(gn‚Ä≤)‚àí1‚Äã(p)subscriptùëëùëõùëùsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùëõ1ùëùd_{n}(p)=(g^{\prime}_{n})^{-1}(p) the modified bandwidth demand function (mBDF). Likewise, we call qn‚Äã(b)=gn‚Ä≤‚Äã(b)subscriptùëûùëõùëèsubscriptsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùëõùëèq_{n}(b)=g^{\prime}_{n}(b) the modified marginal valuation function (mMVF). The network operator can similarly compute the modified market clearing price (mMCP) Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta so that ‚àën=1Ndn‚Äã(Œ∂)=Bsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëëùëõùúÅùêµ\sum_{n=1}^{N}d_{n}(\zeta)=B. Using a similar argument that proves Proposition 2, one can prove Proposition 3 as follows.

Proposition 3.

The mMCP Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta is unique and the resulting bandwidth allocation (b1,‚Ä¶,bN)subscriptùëè1‚Ä¶subscriptùëèùëÅ(b_{1},...,b_{N}) maximizes ‚àën=1N[(1‚àíŒ±)‚Äãfn‚àó‚Äã(bn)+Œ±‚Äãlog‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(b))]superscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅdelimited-[]1ùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùõº1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëè\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left[(1-\alpha)f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})+\alpha\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b))\right].

Proof.

Because fn‚àó‚Äã(b)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèf^{*}_{n}(b) is a concave increasing function, log‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(b))1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëè\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b)) is also concave and increasing. This further shows that gn‚Äã(b)subscriptùëîùëõùëèg_{n}(b) is concave and increasing. Following similar arguments in the proof of Theorem 2 proves the bandwidth allocation as a result of mMCP maximizes ‚àën=1Ngn‚Äã(bn)superscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscriptùëîùëõsubscriptùëèùëõ\sum_{n=1}^{N}g_{n}(b_{n}). ‚àé

The parameter Œ±ùõº\alpha makes a tradeoff between efficiency and fairness. On the one hand, setting Œ±=0ùõº0\alpha=0 reduces the problem to the total FL frequency maximization problem. On the other hand, setting Œ±=1ùõº1\alpha=1 achieves proportional fairness among the service providers.

V-C Bandwidth Allocation and Charging Rules

Now, we are ready to describe the bandwidth allocation and charging rules in fairness-adjusted multi-bid auction. In this subsection, each service provider nùëõn submits only a multi-bid sn=(sn1,‚Ä¶,snM)subscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùë†1ùëõ‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëÄùëõs_{n}=(s^{1}_{n},...,s^{M}_{n}) instead of the complete FL frequency function fn‚àó‚Äã(b)subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõùëèf^{*}_{n}(b). However, we will assume that the service providers are truthfully submitting their bids, which will be proven indeed true in the next subsection. Specifically, we say that a bid snm=(bnm,pnm)subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõs^{m}_{n}=(b^{m}_{n},p^{m}_{n}) is truthful if the bandwidth demand bnmsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõb^{m}_{n} and the price pnmsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõp^{m}_{n} that FL service provider nùëõn is willing to pay satisfy the mBDF because it reveals FL service provider nùëõn‚Äôs true valuation of bandwidth after taking into consideration the fairness-adjusted costs. A multi-bid is truthful if all bids are truthful.

Definition 1.

(Truthful Multi-bid) A multi-bid sn=(sn1,‚Ä¶,snM)subscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùë†1ùëõ‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëÄùëõs_{n}=(s^{1}_{n},...,s^{M}_{n}) is truthful if ‚àÄmfor-allùëö\forall m, snm=(bnm,pnm)subscriptsuperscriptùë†ùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõs^{m}_{n}=(b^{m}_{n},p^{m}_{n}) is such that pnm=gn‚Ä≤‚Äã(bnm)subscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëõ‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõp^{m}_{n}=g_{n}^{\prime}(b^{m}_{n}).

The network operator does not know the BDF (and hence the mBDF) of each FL service provider nùëõn because it does not have access to the FL frequency function fn‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõf^{*}_{n}. Nonetheless, suppose service provider nùëõn submitted a truthful multi-bid snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n}, then the operator can compute a pseudo-mBDF using these bids to have some idea of the actual mBDF. Specifically, given the submitted multi-bid snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n}, a left-continuous step function can be used to describe the pseudo-mBDF as follows,

d¬Øn‚Äã(p)={0,if‚ÄãpnM<pmax1‚â§m‚â§M‚Å°{bnm:pnm‚â•p},otherwisesubscript¬Øùëëùëõùëùcases0ifsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëÄùëõùëùsubscript1ùëöùëÄ:subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõùëùotherwise\bar{d}_{n}(p)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}0,&\text{if}~{}p^{M}_{n}<p\\ \max_{1\leq m\leq M}\{b^{m}_{n}:p^{m}_{n}\geq p\},&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (22)

Essentially, the pseudo-mBDF uses bnmsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõb^{m}_{n} to approximate the bandwidth demand for prices in the range (pnm‚àí1,pnm]subscriptsuperscriptùëùùëö1ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõ(p^{m-1}_{n},p^{m}_{n}]. Similarly, the operator can also construct a pseudo-mMVF (pseudo-MVF), an approximation of service provider nùëõn‚Äôs actual mMVF using the submitted multi-bid, as follows,

q¬Øn‚Äã(b)={0,if‚Äãbn1<bmax1‚â§m‚â§M‚Å°{pnm:bnm‚â•b},otherwisesubscript¬Øùëûùëõùëècases0ifsubscriptsuperscriptùëè1ùëõùëèsubscript1ùëöùëÄ:subscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõùëèotherwise\bar{q}_{n}(b)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}0,&\text{if}~{}b^{1}_{n}<b\\ \max_{1\leq m\leq M}\{p^{m}_{n}:b^{m}_{n}\geq b\},&\text{otherwise}\end{array}\right. (23)

In other words, the pseudo-mMVF uses pnmsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõp^{m}_{n} to approximate the marginal value for bandwidth allocation in the range [bnm,bnm+1)subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëöùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëèùëö1ùëõ[b^{m}_{n},b^{m+1}_{n}). We illustrate the pseudo-mBDF and pseudo-mMVF in Figure 3.

The aggregated pseudo-mBDF is the sum of pseudo-mBDFs of all FL service providers:

d¬Ø‚Äã(p)=‚àën=1Nd¬Øn‚Äã(p)¬Øùëëùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscript¬Øùëëùëõùëù\displaystyle\bar{d}(p)=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\bar{d}_{n}(p) (24)

The pseudo-mMCP Œ∂¬Ø¬ØùúÅ\bar{\zeta} is the largest possible price so that the aggregated pseudo-mBDF exceeds the total available bandwidth, i.e.,

Œ∂¬Ø=sup{p:d¬Ø‚Äã(p)>B}¬ØùúÅsupremumconditional-setùëù¬Øùëëùëùùêµ\displaystyle\bar{\zeta}=\sup\{p:\bar{d}(p)>B\} (25)

This implies that reducing the mMCP by just a little bit will result in the supply (i.e., the total available bandwidth BùêµB) being no greater than the demand. Because every individual pseudo-mBDF function is a step function with KùêæK steps, the aggregated pseudo-mBDF is also a step function with at most N‚ÄãKùëÅùêæNK steps. Therefore, the complexity of computing Œ∂¬Ø¬ØùúÅ\bar{\zeta} is at most O‚Äã(N‚ÄãK)ùëÇùëÅùêæO(NK).

Next, we describe our bandwidth allocation and charging rules. For notational convenience, we denote y‚Äã(x+)=limz‚Üíx,z>xy‚Äã(x)ùë¶superscriptùë•subscriptformulae-sequence‚Üíùëßùë•ùëßùë•ùë¶ùë•y(x^{+})=\lim_{z\to x,z>x}y(x) when this limit exists for a function y:‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù:ùë¶‚Üí‚Ñù‚Ñùy:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} and all x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in\mathbb{R}.

V-C1 Bandwidth allocation

With the pseudo-mMCP Œ∂¬Ø¬ØùúÅ\bar{\zeta}, our bandwidth allocation rule is as follows: if FL service provider nùëõn submits the multi-bid snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n} (and thereby declares the associated functions d¬Ønsubscript¬Øùëëùëõ\bar{d}_{n} and q¬Ønsubscript¬Øùëûùëõ\bar{q}_{n}), then it receives bandwidth bn‚Äã(sn,s‚àín)subscriptùëèùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõb_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n}), with

bn‚Äã(sn,s‚àín)=d¬Øn‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø+)+d¬Øn‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø)‚àíd¬Øn‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø+)d¬Ø‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø)‚àíd¬Ø‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø+)‚Äã(B‚àíd¬Ø‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø+))subscriptùëèùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscript¬Øùëëùëõsuperscript¬ØùúÅsubscript¬Øùëëùëõ¬ØùúÅsubscript¬Øùëëùëõsuperscript¬ØùúÅ¬Øùëë¬ØùúÅ¬Øùëësuperscript¬ØùúÅùêµ¬Øùëësuperscript¬ØùúÅ\displaystyle b_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})=\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})+\frac{\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})}{\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})}\left(B-\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})\right) (26)

In other words: (1) Each FL service provider nùëõn receives an amount of bandwidth it asks for at the lowest price Œ∂¬Ø+superscript¬ØùúÅ\bar{\zeta}^{+} for which supply exceeds the pseudo-bandwidth demand. (2) If all bandwidth is not allocated yet, the surplus B‚àíd¬Ø‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø+)ùêµ¬Øùëësuperscript¬ØùúÅB-\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta}^{+}) is shared among service providers. This share is done proportionally to d¬Øn‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø)‚àíd¬Øn‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø+)subscript¬Øùëëùëõ¬ØùúÅsubscript¬Øùëëùëõsuperscript¬ØùúÅ\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta}^{+}) as we notice that d¬Ø‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø)‚àíd¬Ø‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø+)=‚àën=1N(d¬Øn‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø)‚àíd¬Øn‚Äã(Œ∂¬Ø+))¬Øùëë¬ØùúÅ¬Øùëësuperscript¬ØùúÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëÅsubscript¬Øùëëùëõ¬ØùúÅsubscript¬Øùëëùëõsuperscript¬ØùúÅ\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\left(\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta})-\bar{d}_{n}(\bar{\zeta}^{+})\right), and ensures that all bandwidth is allocated.

V-C2 Charging

Given the submitted multi-bids sùë†s, each service provider nùëõn is charged a payment cn‚Äã(s)subscriptùëêùëõùë†c_{n}(s) as follows,

cn‚Äã(sn,s‚àín)=‚àëj‚â†n‚à´bj‚Äã(s)bj‚Äã(s‚àín)q¬Øj‚Äã(b)‚Äãùëëb+Œ±‚ãÖ(fn‚àó‚Äã(bn)‚àílog‚Å°(1+fn‚àó‚Äã(bn)))subscriptùëêùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùëóùëõsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùëèùëóùë†subscriptùëèùëósubscriptùë†ùëõsubscript¬Øùëûùëóùëèdifferential-dùëè‚ãÖùõºsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõ1subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõ\displaystyle c_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})=\sum_{j\neq n}\int_{b_{j}(s)}^{b_{j}(s_{-n})}\bar{q}_{j}(b)db+\alpha\cdot(f^{*}_{n}(b_{n})-\log(1+f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}))) (27)

The first term on the right-hand side is based on the exclusion-compensation principle in second-price auction mechanisms [40]: service provider nùëõn pays so as to cover the ‚Äúsocial opportunity cost‚Äù, namely the loss of utility it imposes on all other service providers by its presence. The second term on the right-hand side is the fairness-adjusted cost, which is charged at the end of each period after the actual FL frequency is realized and observed.

Considering both the achieved FL frequency and the payment, FL service provider nùëõn‚Äôs utility is therefore

u‚Äã(s)=fn‚àó‚Äã(bn‚Äã(s))‚àícn‚Äã(s)ùë¢ùë†subscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõùë†subscriptùëêùëõùë†\displaystyle u(s)=f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}(s))-c_{n}(s) (28)

V-D Incentives of Truthful Reporting

In the previous subsection, we assumed that the every service provider truthfully submits its bid. Now, we prove that this assumption indeed ‚Äúapproximately‚Äù holds under the designed bandwidth allocation and charging rules.

We first study the individual rationality of the designed mechanism.

Definition 2.

A mechanism is said to be individual rational if no service provider can be worse off from participating in the auction than if it had declined to participate.

Proposition 4.

If FL service provider nùëõn submits a truthful multi-bid snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n}, then un‚Äã(s)‚â•0subscriptùë¢ùëõùë†0u_{n}(s)\geq 0.

which is equivalent to cn‚Äã(sn,s‚àín)‚â§fn‚àó‚Äã(bn‚Äã(sn,s‚àín))subscriptùëêùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëèùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõc_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})\leq f^{*}_{n}(b_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})). Therefore, u‚Äã(s)‚â•0ùë¢ùë†0u(s)\geq 0. ‚àé

Next, we show that truthful reporting is approximately incentive compatible, i.e., a service provider cannot do much better than simply reveal its true valuation.

Proposition 5.

Consider any truthful multi-bid snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n} for service provider nùëõn, and any other multi-bid s~n‚â†snsubscript~ùë†ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõ\tilde{s}_{n}\neq s_{n}, ‚àÄs‚àínfor-allsubscriptùë†ùëõ\forall s_{-n}, we have

un‚Äã(sn,s‚àín)‚â•un‚Äã(s~n,s‚àín)‚àíŒînsubscriptùë¢ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë¢ùëõsubscript~ùë†ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptŒîùëõ\displaystyle u_{n}(s_{n},s_{-n})\geq u_{n}(\tilde{s}_{n},s_{-n})-\Delta_{n} (30)

with pnM+1=qn‚Äã(0)subscriptsuperscriptùëùùëÄ1ùëõsubscriptùëûùëõ0p^{M+1}_{n}=q_{n}(0) and pn0=p0subscriptsuperscriptùëù0ùëõsubscriptùëù0p^{0}_{n}=p_{0}.

Proof.

The proof follows [Proposition 2, [35]]. ‚àé

The above proposition shows that if service provider nùëõn submits a truthful multi-bid snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n}, then every other multi-bid s~nsubscript~ùë†ùëõ\tilde{s}_{n} necessarily corresponds to an increase of utility no larger than ŒînsubscriptŒîùëõ\Delta_{n}. In other words, a truthful bidding brings service provider nùëõn the best utility possible up to a gap ŒînsubscriptŒîùëõ\Delta_{n}. Importantly, this value does not depend on the number of other service providers or the multi-bids they submit. In the game theoretic terminology, the situation where all service providers submit truthful multi-bids is an ex post ŒîŒî\Delta-Nash equilibrium, where Œî=maxn‚Å°ŒînŒîsubscriptùëõsubscriptŒîùëõ\Delta=\max_{n}\Delta_{n}, in the sense that no service provider could have improved its utility by more than ŒîŒî\Delta if it had submitted a different multi-bid.

V-E An Uniform Multi-Bidding Example

To conclude the multi-bid auction mechanism design, we illustrate a uniform multi-bidding approach as an example of how to decide the multi-bid of an individual service provider. Instead of having the service provider submitting both prices and bandwidth requests, the operator can announce MùëÄM prices (pn1,‚Ä¶,pnM)subscriptsuperscriptùëù1ùëõ‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëùùëÄùëõ(p^{1}_{n},...,p^{M}_{n}) to service provider nùëõn and let service provider nùëõn report its requested bandwidth (bn1,‚Ä¶,bMM)subscriptsuperscriptùëè1ùëõ‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëèùëÄùëÄ(b^{1}_{n},...,b^{M}_{M}) at these price points. This way, the operator has a better control over how the service providers make multi-bids to avoid multi-bids that may result in a large ŒînsubscriptŒîùëõ\Delta_{n}, which may reduce service provider‚Äôs incentives to truthfully report. Because the operator does not know the demand function of service provider nùëõn, a natural approach is to uniformly distribute these MùëÄM prices in the range [p0,pnmax]subscriptùëù0subscriptsuperscriptùëùmaxùëõ[p_{0},p^{\text{max}}_{n}] where pnmaxsubscriptsuperscriptùëùmaxùëõp^{\text{max}}_{n} is the largest price at which the service provider may still request a positive amount of bandwidth. Specifically,

pnmax=pn‚Äã(0)=fn‚àó‚Ä≤‚Äã(0)=(‚àëk=1KnŒ±n,k)‚àí1=(‚àëk=1Kn(snDTrkDT+snUTrkUT))‚àí1subscriptsuperscriptùëùmaxùëõsubscriptùëùùëõ0superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëìùëõ‚Ä≤0superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1subscriptùêæùëõsubscriptùõºùëõùëò1superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëò1subscriptùêæùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùë†DTùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëüDTùëòsubscriptsuperscriptùë†UTùëõsubscriptsuperscriptùëüUTùëò1\displaystyle p^{\text{max}}_{n}=p_{n}(0)={f^{*}_{n}}^{\prime}(0)=\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K_{n}}\alpha_{n,k}\right)^{-1}=\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K_{n}}(\frac{s^{\text{DT}}_{n}}{r^{\text{DT}}_{k}}+\frac{s^{\text{UT}}_{n}}{r^{\text{UT}}_{k}})\right)^{-1} (32)

Assume that the network operator has prior knowledge K¬Ønsubscript¬Øùêæùëõ\underline{K}_{n}, s¬ØnDTsubscriptsuperscript¬Øùë†DTùëõ\underline{s}^{\text{DT}}_{n}, s¬ØnUTsubscriptsuperscript¬Øùë†UTùëõ\underline{s}^{\text{UT}}_{n}, r¬ØnDTsubscriptsuperscript¬ØùëüDTùëõ\bar{r}^{\text{DT}}_{n} and r¬ØnUTsubscriptsuperscript¬ØùëüUTùëõ\bar{r}^{\text{UT}}_{n} on the lower/upper bounds on the parameters, then pnmaxsubscriptsuperscriptùëùmaxùëõp^{\text{max}}_{n} can be upper bounded by

pnmax‚â§K¬Øn‚àí1‚ãÖ(s¬ØnDTr¬ØnDT+s¬ØnUTr¬ØnUT)‚àí1‚âúp¬Ønmaxsubscriptsuperscriptùëùmaxùëõ‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscript¬Øùêæùëõ1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript¬Øùë†DTùëõsubscriptsuperscript¬ØùëüDTùëõsubscriptsuperscript¬Øùë†UTùëõsubscriptsuperscript¬ØùëüUTùëõ1‚âúsubscriptsuperscript¬Øùëùmaxùëõ\displaystyle p^{\text{max}}_{n}\leq\underline{K}_{n}^{-1}\cdot\left(\frac{\underline{s}^{\text{DT}}_{n}}{\bar{r}^{\text{DT}}_{n}}+\frac{\underline{s}^{\text{UT}}_{n}}{\bar{r}^{\text{UT}}_{n}}\right)^{-1}\triangleq\bar{p}^{\text{max}}_{n} (33)

Thus, the operator can set the uniform prices as

pnm=p0+m‚ãÖp¬Ønmax‚àíp0M+1,‚àÄm={1,‚Ä¶,M}formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëöùëõsubscriptùëù0‚ãÖùëösubscriptsuperscript¬Øùëùmaxùëõsubscriptùëù0ùëÄ1for-allùëö1‚Ä¶ùëÄ\displaystyle p^{m}_{n}=p_{0}+m\cdot\frac{\bar{p}^{\text{max}}_{n}-p_{0}}{M+1},\forall m=\{1,...,M\} (34)

Note that there is an intrinsic trade-off on the choice of MùëÄM. On the one hand, a large MùëÄM allows the pseudo-BDF and pseudo-MVF to more accurately reflect the true BDF and MVF at an increased complexity and signaling overhead. On the other hand, a smaller MùëÄM makes multi-biding easier but the discrepancy between the pseudo functions and the true functions will introduce a larger performance loss.

VI Simulations

In this section, we conduct simulations to evaluate the performance of the proposed methods.

VI-A Simulation Setup

The simulated wireless network adopts an OFDMA system with a total bandwidth of B=10ùêµ10B=10 MHz. The period length is set as T=20‚Äãsùëá20ùë†T=20s. The number of clients of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 25. In every period, a new FL task may start following a scheduled plan, which is defined by a Poisson distribution with the mean interval parrivesubscriptùëùarrivep_{\text{arrive}}. By tuning parrivesubscriptùëùarrivep_{\text{arrive}}, we adjust the FL service demand, and a smaller parrivesubscriptùëùarrivep_{\text{arrive}} will more likely lead to more concurrent FL services in a period as an FL service often lasts multiple periods. Each FL service has a pre-determined target training accuracy, and when the accuracy reaches the target, the FL service terminates and exits the wireless network. The clients‚Äô wireless channel gain is modeled as independent free-space fading where the average path loss is from a Normal distribution with different mean and variance in different circumstances. The variance of the complex white Gaussian channel noise is set as 10‚àí12superscript101210^{-12}. For each client, the local training time is uniformly randomly drawn from [0.01,0.05]0.010.05[0.01,0.05] s. We fix the global aggregation time to be 1√ó10‚àí51superscript1051\times 10^{-5}. We consider typical neural network sizes in the range of [0.2,0.5]0.20.5[0.2,0.5] Mbits. The upload transmission power is uniformly randomly between 0.05 and 0.15 W, and the download transmission power is uniformly randomly between 0.1 and 0.3 W.

VI-B Convergence of DISBA in the Cooperative Case

We first illustrate the convergence behavior of DISBA in the cooperative FL service provider case in a representative period with 5 concurrent FL services. These services have 10, 12, 14, 16, 18 clients, respectively. In Figure 5, we show the computed FL frequency for each service provider before convergence. As Figure 5 shows, the bandwidth allocation quickly converges to the optimal allocation for a convergence tolerance gap œµ=1‚Äãe‚àí3italic-œµ1ùëí3\epsilon=1e-3. Eventually, the resulting FL frequencies of these FL services in this period are reported in Table I. We further show in Table II the computation time of DISBA for different values of the tolerance gap and step size. The time values are measured on a desktop computer with Intel Core i5-9400 2.9GHz GPU and 16GB memory.

VI-C Fairness-adjusted Multi-bid Auction in the Selfish Case

We perform fairness-adjusted multi-bid auction in the same representative period as in the last subsection, with M=5ùëÄ5M=5 and Œ±=0.5ùõº0.5\alpha=0.5. The pseudo-mBDFs of the FL service providers and the aggregated pseudo-mBDF are illustrated in Figures 7 and 7, respectively. The pseudo-MCP is also shown in Figure 7. Table III reports the resulting bandwidth allocation and achieved FL frequency.

As we briefly mentioned in Section V, there is a trade-off when selecting the number of bids MùëÄM. On the one hand, a larger MùëÄM increases the computational complexity for searching for the pseudo-MCP and determining the eventual bandwidth allocation. On the other hand, a larger MùëÄM improves the precision of the pseudo-MCP, thereby improving the allocation performance. In Figure 8, we demonstrate the overall performance by varying MùëÄM. As can be seen, as MùëÄM increases, the overall performance will increase while each FL service provider needs to submit more bids to the server which will cause transmission delays and data backlogs.

The parameter Œ±ùõº\alpha plays an important role in the selfish owner case, which makes a tradeoff between efficiency and fairness. With a larger Œ±ùõº\alpha, the whole system sees fairness as more important, and conversely, the whole system is more concerned with the overall efficiency. The market clearing price is reflected in Figure 10 and the overall utility is shown in Figure 10. With the increase of Œ±ùõº\alpha, the market clearing price and the total utility will decrease, which can be treated as a concession to achieve fairness between different FL services.

VI-D Performance Comparison

In the following experiments, we compare our proposed algorithms with three benchmark algorithms.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Equal-Client (EC): Bandwidth is equally allocated to the clients. Therefore, each client gets a bandwidth of B/‚àënKnùêµsubscriptùëõsubscriptùêæùëõB/\sum_{n}K_{n}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Equal-Service (ES): Bandwidth is equally allocated to the FL services. That is, each FL service gets a bandwidth of B/NùêµùëÅB/N. However, each FL service provider still performs the optimal intra-service bandwidth allocation among its clients.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Proportional (PP): Each FL service obtains a bandwidth that is proportional to the number of its client. That is, FL service nùëõn obtains a bandwidth of Kn‚àëjKn‚ÄãBsubscriptùêæùëõsubscriptùëósubscriptùêæùëõùêµ\frac{K_{n}}{\sum_{j}K_{n}}B. This bandwidth is further allocated among its clients following the optimal intra-service bandwidth allocation.

We start by comparing the proposed algorithms with benchmarks in the per-period setting. The overall performance is shown in Figure 11. In this setting, there are five FL services with a random number of clients drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 20 and variance 10 and random channel conditions drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 85 and variance 15, and the result is averaged over 20 runs. As can be seen, our DISBA algorithm for the cooperative case (labeled as Coop) has the best performance, and the auction mechanism for the selfish case (labeled as Self) also outperforms the other benchmarks. Although ES and PP also perform the intra-service bandwidth allocation, the heterogeneity of the client number and channel conditions render them suboptimal.

Because FL is a long-term process, we further investigate the long-term performance of the proposed algorithms. In the long-term setting, 10 FL services join the wireless network at different times controlled by the parrivesubscriptùëùarrivep_{\text{arrive}}-parameterized Poisson process and the FL service will be removed from the wireless network when its test accuracy has converged. Although the convergence of FL is complexly affected by many factors including the adopted FL algorithm, dataset and the selected clients, we assume that each of these 10 FL services require 2000 FL rounds, which is a typical value observed in the literature [2], to reach convergence in order to provide a meaningful comparison of the algorithms in a controlled environment. Whenever a FL service has been run for 2000 rounds, it exits the system.

Figure 12 illustrates the average duration (in terms of the number of periods) of all FL services by running different algorithms for parrive=5subscriptùëùarrive5p_{\text{arrive}}=5, where the client number of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 25 and variance 15 and the channel condition of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 85 and variance 15. The results are averaged over 20 runs. We can see that the proposed algorithms achieve the smallest average duration compared to the benchmarks, confirming their fast FL convergence even in the long-run.

Next, we study the impact of the client number heterogeneity (which reflects the FL service size heterogeneity) on the performance of different algorithms. To this end, the client number of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 25 and we change the variance between 0 and 15 to adjust the heterogeneity degree. The result is shown in Figure 13: as the variance increases (i.e. a higher degree of heterogeneity), the mean of the average duration decreases, while the standard deviation of average duration increases. This is understandable because a higher degree of heterogeneity causes wireless bandwidth to be more unevenly distributed among the FL services, thereby degrading the overall FL performance. Notably, the performance gain of our proposed algorithms increases as the variance increases, which demonstrates the superior ability of our algorithms to handle the heterogeneous case.

Furthermore, we also investigate the impact of the channel condition heterogeneity on the FL performance. In these simulations, the average channel condition of a FL service is drawn from a Normal distribution with mean 85 and we change the variance between 0 and 15 to adjust the heterogeneity degree. The channel conditions of clients of this FL are further drawn from a Normal distribution with a mean being the instantiated average channel condition. In Figure 14, we observe a similar phenomenon as in Figure 13, which further confirms the advantage of adopting our proposed algorithms.

Finally, we study the influence of the mean arrival interval parameter parrivesubscriptùëùarrivep_{\text{arrive}} on the resulting average FL duration. in Figure 15, with the increasing of parrivesubscriptùëùarrivep_{\text{arrive}}, the average duration of the FL services decreases. This is because when parrivesubscriptùëùarrivep_{\text{arrive}} is small, many FL services pile up and co-exist in the wireless network, thereby reducing the wireless bandwidth an individual FL service can receive.

VII Conclusion

This paper studied a bandwidth allocation problem for multiple FL services in a wireless network, which has not been well studied in the literature. The considered problem consists of two interconnected subproblems, intra-service resource allocation, and inter-service resource allocation. By solving these problems, we optimally allocate bandwidth resources to multiple FL services and their corresponding clients to speed up the training process and meanwhile guarantee fairness for both cooperative and selfish FL service providers cases. Our method has shown superior performance compared to the benchmarks. However, there are several future research works that can be done to extend the impact of this work. For example, this paper takes FL frequency as the key metric to be optimized, but the true performance of FL is affected by the dataset, federated optimization algorithm, and many others. In addition, when a client can simultaneously participate in multiple FL services, resource allocation has to consider both the wireless bandwidth and client computing resources.
